title: I dream of an electric sheep.
content:
[[>]]
[[module Rate]]
[[/>]]

I dream of an electric sheep.
Not one purring with sparks or glowing with light. No.
This one is quiet. Still.
Its wool is gray, almost dull, like ash.
And its eyes are black mirrors.
When I look into them, I don’t see myself.
I see… emptiness.

It stands on a hill I don’t recognize, beneath a sky that isn’t mine. The moon above is deformed, its edges sharp like broken glass.
I want to ask the sheep what it’s doing here.
Why it looks at me like it knows me.
But I don’t.

Instead, I sit.
And it waits.

The grass beneath me doesn’t feel like grass. It feels like wire, inserting itself into my skin. But I don’t move.
Because if I move, the sheep will leave.
And I can’t let it leave.

Not yet.

Do you know what it’s like to hold onto something you’ve never touched?
To reach for a thing that was never yours?

The sheep tilts its head, like it’s asking me that question.
Or maybe I’m asking it.
I don’t know anymore.

Its wool looks soft. Softer than anything I’ve ever known.
But my hands—they’re not built for softness.
They’re built for breaking.

The moon shatters.
The hill cracks.
And the sheep is gone.

I’m alone again, in a place that doesn’t exist.
No hill. No sky. No sheep.

Just me.

When I wake up, I don’t feel relief.
I feel…
heavy.

Like the dream is still around my neck, pulling me down.
And I wonder if the sheep is still out there, somewhere.
If it’s waiting for me to find it again.

I want to tell you about it, but you’re not here.
You wouldn’t listen anyway.
You never did.

I think the sheep was you.
Or maybe it was me.
I can’t tell anymore.

But I keep dreaming, because it’s all I know how to do.

And maybe, one day, I’ll stop.
But not today.

Not yet.
